title: A Trefftz Continuous Galerkin method for Helmholtz problems
summary: This work introduces a novel Trefftz Continuous Galerkin (TCG) method for 2D Helmholtz problems based on evanescent plane waves (EPWs). We construct a new globally-conforming discrete space, departing from standard discontinuous Trefftz formulations, and investigate its approximation properties, providing wavenumber-explicit best-approximation error estimates. The mesh is defined by intersecting the domain with a Cartesian grid, and the basis functions are continuous in the whole computational domain, compactly supported, and can be expressed as simple linear combinations of EPWs within each element. This ensures they remain local solutions to the Helmholtz equation and allows the system matrix to be assembled in closed form for polygonal domains. The discrete space provides stable approximations with bounded coefficients and spectral accuracy for analytic Helmholtz solutions. The approximation error is proved to decay exponentially both at a fixed frequency, with respect to the discretization parameters, and along suitable sequences of increasing wavenumbers, with the number of degrees of freedom scaling linearly with the frequency. Numerical results confirm these theoretical estimates for the full Galerkin error.

AI.tldr: A novel Trefftz Continuous Galerkin method using evanescent plane waves for 2D Helmholtz problems, featuring continuous basis functions with exponential error decay and linear scaling with frequency.
AI.motivation: To develop a continuous Galerkin method for Helmholtz problems that avoids the limitations of standard discontinuous Trefftz formulations, providing stable approximations with bounded coefficients and spectral accuracy for analytic solutions.
AI.method: Constructs a globally-conforming discrete space using evanescent plane waves (EPWs) on a Cartesian grid mesh. Basis functions are continuous, compactly supported, and expressed as linear combinations of EPWs within each element, ensuring they remain local solutions to the Helmholtz equation. System matrix assembly in closed form for polygonal domains.
AI.result: Provides wavenumber-explicit best-approximation error estimates with exponential decay both at fixed frequency (with respect to discretization parameters) and along increasing wavenumber sequences. Number of degrees of freedom scales linearly with frequency. Numerical results confirm theoretical estimates for full Galerkin error.
AI.conclusion: The Trefftz Continuous Galerkin method with evanescent plane waves offers an effective approach for Helmholtz problems with continuous basis functions, providing spectral accuracy, stable approximations with bounded coefficients, and favorable computational scaling with frequency.

title: Sampling on Metric Graphs
summary: Metric graphs are structures obtained by associating edges in a standard graph with segments of the real line and gluing these segments at the vertices of the graph. The resulting structure has a natural metric that allows for the study of differential operators and stochastic processes on the graph. Brownian motions in these domains have been extensively studied theoretically using their generators. However, less work has been done on practical algorithms for simulating these processes. We introduce the first algorithm for simulating Brownian motions on metric graphs through a timestep splitting Euler-Maruyama-based discretization of their corresponding stochastic differential equation. By applying this scheme to Langevin diffusions on metric graphs, we also obtain the first algorithm for sampling on metric graphs. We provide theoretical guarantees on the number of timestep splittings required for the algorithm to converge to the underlying stochastic process. We also show that the exit probabilities of the simulated particle converge to the vertex-edge jump probabilities of the underlying stochastic differential equation as the timestep goes to zero. Finally, since this method is highly parallelizable, we provide fast, memory-aware implementations of our algorithm in the form of custom CUDA kernels that are up to ~8000x faster than a GPU implementation using PyTorch on simple star metric graphs. Beyond simple star graphs, we benchmark our algorithm on a real cortical vascular network extracted from a DuMuX tissue-perfusion model for tracer transport. Our algorithm is able to run stable simulations with timesteps significantly larger than the stable limit of the finite volume method used in DuMuX while also achieving speedups of up to ~1500x.

AI.tldr: First algorithm for simulating Brownian motions on metric graphs using timestep splitting Euler-Maruyama discretization, with theoretical guarantees and highly parallelizable CUDA implementation achieving up to 8000x speedup.
AI.motivation: While Brownian motions on metric graphs have been extensively studied theoretically, there's a lack of practical algorithms for simulating these processes. The paper aims to bridge this gap by developing the first simulation algorithm for Brownian motions on metric graphs.
AI.method: Develops a timestep splitting Euler-Maruyama-based discretization of stochastic differential equations on metric graphs. The method is applied to Langevin diffusions to enable sampling on metric graphs. The algorithm is highly parallelizable and implemented as custom CUDA kernels.
AI.result: Provides theoretical guarantees on convergence and exit probabilities. Achieves up to ~8000x speedup over GPU PyTorch implementations on simple star graphs, and up to ~1500x speedup on real cortical vascular networks while maintaining stability with larger timesteps than finite volume methods.
AI.conclusion: The paper presents the first practical algorithm for simulating Brownian motions on metric graphs with strong theoretical guarantees and exceptional computational performance through custom CUDA implementations, enabling efficient simulation and sampling on complex metric graph structures.

title: Two Variations on the XTrace Algorithm
summary: This paper studies two potential modifications of XTrace (Epperly et al., SIMAX 45(1):1-23, 2024), a randomized algorithm for estimating the trace of a matrix. The first is a variance reduction step that averages the output of XTrace over right-multiplications of the test vectors by random orthogonal matrices. The second is to form a low-rank approximation to the matrix using the whole Krylov space produced by the test vectors, rather than the output of a single power iteration as is used by XTrace. Experiments on synthetic data show that the first modification offers only slight benefits in practice, while the second can lead to significant improvements depending on the spectrum of the matrix.

AI.tldr: Two modifications to XTrace algorithm: 1) variance reduction via averaging over orthogonal matrix rotations, 2) using full Krylov space for low-rank approximation instead of single power iteration.
AI.motivation: To improve the XTrace algorithm for matrix trace estimation by reducing variance and potentially achieving better accuracy through more sophisticated use of the generated Krylov space.
AI.method: Two modifications: 1) Averaging XTrace outputs over right-multiplications by random orthogonal matrices for variance reduction. 2) Using the entire Krylov space produced by test vectors to form low-rank approximation, rather than just a single power iteration.
AI.result: Experiments on synthetic data show the variance reduction modification offers only slight benefits, while the Krylov space modification can lead to significant improvements depending on the matrix spectrum.
AI.conclusion: The full Krylov space approach shows more promise than the variance reduction technique, with performance gains dependent on the matrix spectral properties.

title: Error estimates for semi-Lagrangian schemes with higher-order interpolation for conservation laws with dispersive terms
summary: We establish error estimates for semi-Lagrangian schemes for the initial value problem of one-dimensional conservation laws with a dispersive term, including the Korteweg--de Vries equation. The schemes considered in this paper are based on the semi-Lagrangian technique combined with spatial discretization by higher-order interpolation operators. For the semi-Lagrangian schemes equipped with the spline or Hermite interpolation operators of order $ 2 s - 1 $, we derive an $L^2$-error estimate of $ O (Δt^r + h^{2s} / Δt) $ and an $ H^s $-error estimate of $ O (Δt^r + h^{s} / \sqrt{Δt}) $, where $ h $ and $ Δt $ denote the spatial mesh size and the time step size, respectively, and $ r \in \lparen 0, 1\rbrack $ is a parameter determined by the discretization of the dispersive term. A key step in the analysis is to establish the stability of the interpolation operators. Under suitable assumptions, interpolation operators of order $ 2s - 1 $ are stable with respect to the $ H^s $-norm as well as a weighted $ H^s $-norm. The weighted $H^s$-norm depends on $h$ and $Δt$, and it reduces to the $L^2$-norm in the limit $ h \to 0 $.

AI.tldr: Error estimates for semi-Lagrangian schemes applied to 1D conservation laws with dispersive terms (including KdV), using high-order interpolation operators.
AI.motivation: To develop and analyze accurate numerical methods for dispersive conservation laws, which are important in fluid dynamics and wave propagation, by establishing rigorous error estimates for semi-Lagrangian schemes.
AI.method: Semi-Lagrangian schemes combined with high-order spatial interpolation operators (spline or Hermite interpolation of order 2s-1). Analysis focuses on stability of interpolation operators with respect to H^s-norm and weighted H^s-norm.
AI.result: Derived L^2-error estimate of O(Δt^r + h^{2s}/Δt) and H^s-error estimate of O(Δt^r + h^s/√Δt), where r ∈ (0,1] depends on dispersive term discretization. Established stability of interpolation operators in relevant norms.
AI.conclusion: Semi-Lagrangian schemes with high-order interpolation provide effective numerical methods for dispersive conservation laws with quantifiable error bounds, where interpolation stability plays crucial role in analysis.

title: Towards a fully differentiable digital twin for solar cells
summary: Maximizing energy yield (EY) - the total electric energy generated by a solar cell within a year at a specific location - is crucial in photovoltaics (PV), especially for emerging technologies. Computational methods provide the necessary insights and guidance for future research. However, existing simulations typically focus on only isolated aspects of solar cells. This lack of consistency highlights the need for a framework unifying all computational levels, from material to cell properties, for accurate prediction and optimization of EY prediction. To address this challenge, a differentiable digital twin, Sol(Di)$^2$T, is introduced to enable comprehensive end-to-end optimization of solar cells. The workflow starts with material properties and morphological processing parameters, followed by optical and electrical simulations. Finally, climatic conditions and geographic location are incorporated to predict the EY. Each step is either intrinsically differentiable or replaced with a machine-learned surrogate model, enabling not only accurate EY prediction but also gradient-based optimization with respect to input parameters. Consequently, Sol(Di)$^2$T extends EY predictions to previously unexplored conditions. Demonstrated for an organic solar cell, the proposed framework marks a significant step towards tailoring solar cells for specific applications while ensuring maximal performance.

AI.tldr: Sol(Di)²T is a differentiable digital twin framework for end-to-end optimization of solar cell energy yield, unifying material properties, processing, optical/electrical simulations, and climatic conditions.
AI.motivation: Existing solar cell simulations focus on isolated aspects, lacking consistency. There's a need for a unified framework from material to cell properties for accurate energy yield prediction and optimization, especially for emerging PV technologies.
AI.method: Introduces Sol(Di)²T, a differentiable digital twin workflow that starts with material properties and processing parameters, followed by optical/electrical simulations, and incorporates climatic/geographic conditions. Each step is either intrinsically differentiable or uses machine-learned surrogate models.
AI.result: Enables comprehensive end-to-end optimization of solar cells, accurate energy yield prediction, and gradient-based optimization with respect to input parameters. Extends energy yield predictions to previously unexplored conditions.
AI.conclusion: The framework represents a significant step toward tailoring solar cells for specific applications while ensuring maximal performance, demonstrated for organic solar cells.

title: Splash-squeeze singularities and analytic breakdown in ideal incompressible MHD
summary:
We construct splash-squeeze singularities for the free boundary ideal incompressible plasma-vacuum system, in which two arcs of the plasma boundary come together to form a smooth, glancing self-intersection. As the interface self-intersects, Sobolev norms remain bounded, although analyticity is necessarily lost. This contrasts classical splash singularities, in which solutions remain analytic up to the time of self-intersection.
  The narrowing gap bounded by these arcs is not occupied by plasma, as squeezing the plasma itself would cause blow-up in Sobolev norms. Instead, the gap represents the region outside the plasma, a vacuum carrying a nontrivial magnetic field. The plasma on either side pinches the field as the gap closes, and, in response, the field flattens to infinite order at the intersection point (and nowhere else), thereby forming an analytic singularity. This gives the first example of analytic breakdown without Sobolev blow-up in a locally well-posed free-boundary incompressible fluid system, and can be viewed as the first rigorous construction of a squeeze-type singularity, in which we study and quantify the precise behavior of an active, incompressible vector field as it is completely pinched off by a free-boundary in finite time.
  The proof combines a magnetically-aligned Lagrangian formulation of ideal MHD together with weighted elliptic estimates in the vacuum that remain uniform as the width of the gap tends to zero. Our framework may provide a starting point for the analysis of squeeze-type singularities in other incompressible fluid models.

AI.tldr: Construct splash-squeeze singularities for plasma-vacuum system where plasma boundary self-intersects smoothly, with bounded Sobolev norms but loss of analyticity, contrasting classical splash singularities.
AI.motivation: To study squeeze-type singularities in free-boundary incompressible fluid systems, specifically how plasma boundaries can self-intersect without Sobolev blow-up but with analytic breakdown, providing first rigorous construction of such phenomena.
AI.method: Combines magnetically-aligned Lagrangian formulation of ideal MHD with weighted elliptic estimates in vacuum that remain uniform as gap width tends to zero.
AI.result: First example of analytic breakdown without Sobolev blow-up in locally well-posed free-boundary incompressible fluid system; magnetic field flattens to infinite order at intersection point forming analytic singularity.
AI.conclusion: Framework provides starting point for analyzing squeeze-type singularities in other incompressible fluid models, demonstrating novel singularity formation mechanism in plasma-vacuum systems.

title: A novel method for thermal noise reduction, enabling measurements of broadband, low-amplitude electron temperature fluctuations using individual radiometer channels
comment: 10 pages, 8 figures. The following article has been submitted to Review of Scientific Instruments. After it is published, it will be found at https://pubs.aip.org/aip/rsi
summary: A new analysis method has been developed for measurements of broadband, low-amplitude turbulent electron temperature fluctuations in fusion plasmas using individual radiometer channels of a Correlation Electron Cyclotron Emission (CECE) diagnostic. This method takes advantage of differences in the correlation time of thermal noise compared to the correlation time of plasma fluctuations in fusion reactors. The validation of this single-channel method is demonstrated using comparisons with the standard dual-channel radiometer spectral decorrelation method for measurements of turbulent electron temperature fluctuations in the core and edge of low confinement (L), improved confinement (I), and high confinement (H)-mode plasmas at the ASDEX Upgrade tokamak.

AI.tldr: New single-channel method for measuring turbulent electron temperature fluctuations in fusion plasmas using CECE diagnostics, validated against standard dual-channel approach.
AI.motivation: Need improved methods for measuring broadband, low-amplitude turbulent electron temperature fluctuations in fusion plasmas, particularly for CECE diagnostics where standard methods require dual channels.
AI.method: Single-channel analysis method that exploits differences in correlation times between thermal noise and plasma fluctuations in fusion reactors. Uses individual radiometer channels of CECE diagnostic.
AI.result: Method validated through comparisons with standard dual-channel radiometer spectral decorrelation method across various plasma confinement modes (L, I, H-mode) at ASDEX Upgrade tokamak, in both core and edge regions.
AI.conclusion: New single-channel method provides reliable measurement of turbulent electron temperature fluctuations, offering potential advantages over dual-channel approaches for CECE diagnostics in fusion plasma research.

title: Numerical verification of PolyDG algebraic solvers for the pseudo-stress Stokes problem
summary: This work focuses on the development of efficient solvers for the pseudo-stress formulation of the unsteady Stokes problem, discretised by means of a discontinuous Galerkin method on polytopal grids (PolyDG). The introduction of the pseudo-stress variable is motivated by the growing interest in non-Newtonian flow models and coupled interface problems, where the stress field plays a fundamental role in the physical description. The space-time discretisation of the problem is obtained by combining the PolyDG approach in space with the implicit Euler method for time integration. The resulting linear system, characterised by a symmetric, positive, definite matrix, exhibits deteriorating convergence with standard solvers as the time step decreases. To address this issue, we investigate two tailored strategies: deflated Conjugate Gradient, which mitigates the effect of the most problematic eigenmodes, and collective Block-Jacobi, which exploits the block structure of the system matrix. Numerical experiments show that both approaches yield iteration counts effectively independent of $Δt$, ensuring robust performance with respect to the time step. Future work will focus on extending this robustness to the spatial discretisation parameter $h$ by integrating multigrid strategies with the time-robust solvers developed in this study.

AI.tldr: Developed time-robust solvers for pseudo-stress Stokes problems using PolyDG discretization, addressing convergence deterioration with small time steps through deflated CG and Block-Jacobi methods.
AI.motivation: Growing interest in non-Newtonian flow models and coupled interface problems where stress field plays fundamental role; need for efficient solvers for pseudo-stress formulation of unsteady Stokes problems.
AI.method: Combined PolyDG (discontinuous Galerkin on polytopal grids) in space with implicit Euler for time integration; investigated deflated Conjugate Gradient (mitigates problematic eigenmodes) and collective Block-Jacobi (exploits block structure) to address convergence deterioration with small time steps.
AI.result: Both deflated CG and Block-Jacobi approaches yield iteration counts effectively independent of time step Δt, ensuring robust performance with respect to time step; linear system is symmetric positive definite.
AI.conclusion: Developed time-robust solvers for pseudo-stress Stokes problems; future work will extend robustness to spatial discretization parameter h by integrating multigrid strategies with the time-robust solvers.

title: Out-of-equilibrium modeling of lyotropic liquid crystals: from binary simulations to multi-component theory
summary:
We present a thermodynamically consistent theoretical framework for lyotropic liquid crystals (LCs) based on the GENERIC (General Equation for the Non-Equilibrium Reversible-Irreversible Coupling) formalism. This formalism ensures conservation of energy and production of entropy, while coupling concentration, momentum balance, and liquid crystalline order. Starting from a binary nematic-isotropic mixture, we derive a theory for these key variables, which is then extended to multi-component systems.
  The binary equations are solved numerically using a Julia-based solver that relies on an upwind finite-difference scheme, enabling stable and efficient simulations capable of handling multiple time scales while satisfying fundamental mathematical constraints. The results of simulations are consistent with experimental observations of topological core defects in chromonic LCs, as well as flow-driven droplet shape transitions under Couette and Poiseuille flows.
  This work provides a platform for simulations of multi-component lyotropic LCs that can be extended to systems with multiple interfaces, active materials, and materials subject to external fields.

AI.tldr: A thermodynamically consistent framework for lyotropic liquid crystals using GENERIC formalism, with numerical simulations showing agreement with experimental defect patterns and flow-driven transitions.
AI.motivation: To develop a theoretical framework for lyotropic liquid crystals that ensures thermodynamic consistency (energy conservation and entropy production) while coupling concentration, momentum, and liquid crystalline order, which can handle complex multi-component systems.
AI.method: Uses the GENERIC (General Equation for the Non-Equilibrium Reversible-Irreversible Coupling) formalism to derive equations for binary nematic-isotropic mixtures, then extends to multi-component systems. Numerical implementation uses a Julia-based solver with upwind finite-difference scheme for stable simulations across multiple time scales.
AI.result: Simulations show consistency with experimental observations: topological core defects in chromonic LCs, and flow-driven droplet shape transitions under Couette and Poiseuille flows. The framework successfully handles multiple time scales while satisfying fundamental mathematical constraints.
AI.conclusion: Provides a versatile platform for simulating multi-component lyotropic LCs that can be extended to systems with multiple interfaces, active materials, and materials under external fields, offering a thermodynamically consistent approach to complex liquid crystal phenomena.

title: An infinite-dimensional mountain pass theorem with applications to nonlinear elliptic systems
summary: The purpose of this paper is to establish a critical point theorem, which is an infinite-dimensional generalization of the classical generalized Mountain Pass Theorem of P. H. Rabinowitz \cite[Theorem 5.3]{Ra}. As application, we obtain the existence of at least one solution to a semilinear elliptic systems with indefinite weights in $\mathbb{R}^2$.

AI.tldr: Establishes an infinite-dimensional generalization of Rabinowitz's Generalized Mountain Pass Theorem and applies it to prove existence of solutions for semilinear elliptic systems with indefinite weights in ℝ².
AI.motivation: To extend classical critical point theory (specifically Rabinowitz's Generalized Mountain Pass Theorem) to infinite-dimensional settings, enabling application to more complex PDE problems like semilinear elliptic systems with indefinite weights.
AI.method: Develops an infinite-dimensional generalization of the Generalized Mountain Pass Theorem, then applies this new critical point theorem to analyze semilinear elliptic systems with indefinite weights in two-dimensional Euclidean space.
AI.result: Establishes a new critical point theorem and uses it to prove the existence of at least one solution for the specified class of semilinear elliptic systems with indefinite weights in ℝ².
AI.conclusion: Successfully generalizes classical mountain pass theory to infinite dimensions and demonstrates its applicability to solving nonlinear elliptic systems with indefinite weights, providing new existence results for such PDE problems.

title: Integrated Sliding-Short/Probe Tuner with Doorknob Transition for High-Q Cavities
summary:
We present an integrated three-knob tuner that internalizes impedance matching inside the launch adapter of a waveguide-fed, high-$Q$ cavity. The tuner combines a waveguide sliding short, a doorknob transition, and a micrometer-driven adjustable coaxial probe. A transmission-line/ABCD model is derived that maps the three mechanical degrees of freedom to the electrical objectives $Γ\rightarrow 0$, $β$, and $Q_{\rm L}$, explicitly including the fused-silica feedthrough capacitance. The model yields closed-form matching conditions and predicts the critical-coupling set. Full-wave FEM simulations and bench measurements validate the approach: with $h \approx 0.55$~mm and backshort distance $\approx 0.80$~mm, the return loss reaches $|S_{11}| \approx -30$~dB near 17.8--18.1~GHz while sustaining peak electric fields of $\sim 1.8 \times 10^5$~V/m at the nozzle (normalized to 1~W). The measured through loss of the launch assembly is $|S_{21}| \approx 0.7$--$0.8$~dB at resonance.
  A parametric study shows that backshort lengths $L_{\rm {bs}} \geq 0.5 λ_{\rm g}$ excite a parasitic stub resonance, introducing a second $S_{11}$ minimum and localizing energy behind the doorknob; keeping $L_{\rm {bs}} \leq 0.4 λ_g$ avoids this. In helium plasma discharges at $P_{\rm {in}} = 10$~W, \textit{in-situ} retuning of the short and probe maintained a favorable match as the plasma impedance evolved, increasing absorbed power from $\sim 43\%$ to $\sim 76\%$ while increasing helium propellant flow rate from 25 to 351~sccm. The compact tuner eliminates external stub boxes and generalizes to other waveguide-coupled resonators and plasma sources.

AI.tldr: A three-knob impedance tuner integrated into waveguide-fed cavity launch adapter enables precise matching, critical coupling control, and in-situ plasma impedance tracking.
AI.motivation: To eliminate external stub boxes and provide integrated impedance matching for waveguide-coupled high-Q cavities, enabling in-situ tuning for plasma sources with evolving impedance.
AI.method: Integrated tuner combines waveguide sliding short, doorknob transition, and micrometer-driven coaxial probe. Transmission-line/ABCD model maps mechanical adjustments to electrical objectives (Γ→0, β, Q_L). Validated with FEM simulations and bench measurements.
AI.result: Achieved return loss of -30 dB near 17.8-18.1 GHz with 0.7-0.8 dB through loss. In plasma discharges, in-situ retuning increased absorbed power from 43% to 76% as helium flow rate increased from 25 to 351 sccm.
AI.conclusion: Compact integrated tuner successfully eliminates external stub boxes, provides precise impedance matching, and generalizes to other waveguide-coupled resonators and plasma sources.

title: Multigrid p-Robustness at Jacobi Speeds: Efficient Matrix-Free Implementation of Local p-Multigrid Solvers
summary: Vertex-patch smoothers are essential for the robust convergence of geometric multigrid methods in high-order finite element applications, yet their adoption is traditionally hindered by the prohibitive cost of solving local patch problems. This paper presents a high-performance, matrix-free implementation of a p-multigrid local solver that dismantles the trade-off between smoothing effectiveness and computational efficiency. We focus on the practical realization of this iterative approach, leveraging sum-factorization and explicit SIMD vectorization to minimize memory footprint and maximize arithmetic throughput. The performance analysis demonstrates that the solver effectively hides data-fetching latencies and maintains optimal $\mathcal{O}(p^d)$ memory scaling, even when dominated by geometric data on distorted meshes. The result is a robust smoother that rivals the execution speed of simple pointwise smoothers while preserving the convergence benefits of patch-based methods.

AI.tldr: Matrix-free p-multigrid vertex-patch smoother achieves both high smoothing effectiveness and computational efficiency through sum-factorization and SIMD vectorization.
AI.motivation: Vertex-patch smoothers are crucial for robust convergence in high-order finite element multigrid methods, but their adoption has been limited by the high computational cost of solving local patch problems.
AI.method: Developed a high-performance, matrix-free implementation of p-multigrid local solver using sum-factorization and explicit SIMD vectorization to minimize memory footprint and maximize arithmetic throughput.
AI.result: The solver effectively hides data-fetching latencies, maintains optimal O(p^d) memory scaling even on distorted meshes, and achieves execution speed comparable to simple pointwise smoothers while preserving patch-based convergence benefits.
AI.conclusion: The proposed approach successfully dismantles the traditional trade-off between smoothing effectiveness and computational efficiency, resulting in a robust vertex-patch smoother suitable for practical high-order finite element applications.

title: Geant4 Modeling of Energy and Charge Deposition in Satellites Solar Cells
summary: Understanding radiation effects in spacecraft components is critical for predicting long-term performance degradation. In this work, a Geant4 Monte Carlo model is developed to compute charge and energy deposition in satellite solar-cell materials exposed to electrons, protons, and X-ray environments. The model is validated against published experimental and computational benchmarks and shows strong agreement across multiple energy ranges. Power-density deposition profiles are then evaluated for a multi-layer solar-cell structure under blackbody soft X-rays, mono-energetic X-rays, and high-energy electrons. The results show that low-energy X-rays dominate damage in surface layers, while high-energy particles penetrate deeper into semiconductor and substrate layers, posing risk to electronic components. These findings highlight the importance of radiation-specific shielding strategies for space solar-cell design.

AI.tldr: Geant4 Monte Carlo model developed to analyze radiation effects on satellite solar cells, showing low-energy X-rays damage surface layers while high-energy particles penetrate deeper.
AI.motivation: Understanding radiation effects on spacecraft components is critical for predicting long-term performance degradation of satellite systems in space environments.
AI.method: Developed a Geant4 Monte Carlo model to compute charge and energy deposition in satellite solar-cell materials exposed to electrons, protons, and X-ray environments, validated against experimental and computational benchmarks.
AI.result: Model shows strong agreement with benchmarks; power-density deposition profiles reveal low-energy X-rays dominate damage in surface layers, while high-energy particles penetrate deeper into semiconductor and substrate layers.
AI.conclusion: Findings highlight the importance of radiation-specific shielding strategies for space solar-cell design, with different radiation types requiring targeted protection approaches.

title: Asymptotic behavior of solutions to a singular chemotaxis system in multi-dimensions
summary: In this paper, we investigate the optimal large-time behavior of the global solution to a singular chemotaxis system in the whole space $\mathbb{R}^d$ with $d=2,3$. Assuming that the initial data is sufficiently close to an equilibrium state, we first prove the $k$-th order spatial derivative of the global solution converges to its corresponding equilibrium at the optimal rate $(1+t)^{-(\frac{d}{4}+\frac{k}{2})}$, which improve upon the result in [37]. Then, for well-chosen initial data, we also establish lower bounds on the convergence rates, which match those of the heat equation. Our proof relies on a Cole-Hopf type transformation, delicate spectral analysis, the Fourier splitting technique, and energy methods.

AI.tldr: This paper studies optimal large-time behavior of solutions to a singular chemotaxis system in 2D and 3D, proving optimal convergence rates to equilibrium and establishing matching lower bounds.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to understand the precise asymptotic behavior of solutions to singular chemotaxis systems, improving upon previous results that only established suboptimal convergence rates. The authors aim to determine the exact optimal decay rates and establish matching lower bounds to show these rates are sharp.
AI.method: The authors use a Cole-Hopf type transformation to simplify the system, perform delicate spectral analysis of the linearized operator, employ the Fourier splitting technique to handle nonlinear estimates, and use energy methods to establish decay estimates. For lower bounds, they construct well-chosen initial data to match the heat equation decay rates.
AI.result: The main results show that for initial data sufficiently close to equilibrium, the k-th order spatial derivative of the global solution converges to equilibrium at the optimal rate (1+t)^{-(d/4 + k/2)} in ℝ^d with d=2,3. This improves upon previous suboptimal results. Additionally, for well-chosen initial data, they establish matching lower bounds showing these rates are sharp and coincide with heat equation decay rates.
AI.conclusion: The paper successfully establishes optimal convergence rates for singular chemotaxis systems in 2D and 3D, demonstrating that solutions decay to equilibrium at the same rates as the heat equation. The results are sharp, with matching upper and lower bounds, providing a complete picture of the large-time asymptotic behavior for these systems near equilibrium.

title: Laser-driven electrodynamic implosion of fast ions in a thin shell
summary: Collision of laser-driven subrelativistic high density ion flows provides a way to create extremely compressed ion conglomerates and study their properties. This paper presents a theoretical study of the electrodynamic implosion of ions inside a hollow spherical or cylindrical shell irradiated by femtosecond petawatt laser pulses. We propose to apply a very effective mechanism for ion acceleration in a selfconsistent field with strong charge separation, based on the oscillation of laser accelerated fast electrons in this field near the thin shell. Fast electrons are generated on the outer side of the shell under irradiation by the intense laser pulses. It is shown that ions, in particular protons, may be accelerated at the implosion stage to energies of tens and hundreds of MeV when a sub-micrometer shell is irradiated by femtosecond laser pulses with an intensity of 10^21 - 10^23 W cm^-2. .

AI.tldr: Theoretical study of electrodynamic implosion of ions in hollow spherical/cylindrical shells irradiated by femtosecond petawatt lasers, achieving ion acceleration to tens/hundreds of MeV.
AI.motivation: To create extremely compressed ion conglomerates and study their properties through laser-driven subrelativistic high density ion flows.
AI.method: Proposes using laser-driven fast electron oscillations in self-consistent field with strong charge separation near thin shells. Fast electrons generated on outer shell surface by intense femtosecond laser pulses accelerate ions during implosion stage.
AI.result: Ions (particularly protons) can be accelerated to energies of tens and hundreds of MeV when sub-micrometer shells are irradiated by femtosecond laser pulses with intensity of 10^21 - 10^23 W cm^-2.
AI.conclusion: Laser-driven electrodynamic implosion provides effective mechanism for creating highly compressed ion conglomerates and accelerating ions to high energies using petawatt laser systems.

title: An efficient fully decoupled finite element method with second-order accuracy for the micropolar Rayleigh-Benard convection system
summary: The micropolar Rayleigh-B{é}nard convection system, which consists of Navier-Stokes equations, the angular momentum equation, and the heat equation, is a strongly nonlinear, coupled, and saddle point structural multiphysics system. A second-order pressure projection finite element method, which is linear, fully decoupled, and second-order accurate in time, is proposed to simulate the system. Only a few decoupled linear elliptic problems with constant coefficients are solved at each time step, simplifying calculations significantly. The stability analysis of the method is established and the optimal error estimates are derived rigorously with the negative norm technique. Extensive numerical simulations, including 2D and 3D accuracy tests, the lid-driven cavity flow, and the passive-scalar mixing experiment, are carried out to illustrate the effectiveness of the method.

AI.tldr: A second-order pressure projection FEM for micropolar Rayleigh-Bénard convection is proposed, featuring linear, fully decoupled time-stepping with constant-coefficient elliptic solves.
AI.motivation: The micropolar Rayleigh-Bénard convection system is strongly nonlinear, coupled, and has saddle point structure, making it computationally challenging to simulate efficiently.
AI.method: A second-order pressure projection finite element method that is linear, fully decoupled, and second-order accurate in time. At each time step, only decoupled linear elliptic problems with constant coefficients need to be solved.
AI.result: Stability analysis is established, optimal error estimates are derived rigorously using negative norm technique. Extensive numerical simulations including 2D/3D accuracy tests, lid-driven cavity flow, and passive-scalar mixing experiments demonstrate effectiveness.
AI.conclusion: The proposed method successfully addresses the computational challenges of the micropolar Rayleigh-Bénard convection system through a decoupled, efficient finite element approach with proven stability and accuracy.

title: Improved Ising Meson Spectroscopy Simulation on a Noisy Digital Quantum Device
summary: The transverse-field Ising model serves as a paradigm for studying confinement and excitation spectra, particularly the emergence of $E_8$ symmetry near criticality. However, experimentally resolving the Ising meson spectroscopy required to verify these symmetries is challenging on near-term quantum hardware due to the depth of circuits required for real-time evolution. Here, we demonstrate improved spectroscopy of confined excitations using two distinct error-resilient circuit construction techniques on the IBM Torino device: first-order Trotter decomposition utilizing native fractional gates, and a tensor-network-based circuit compression via Riemannian optimization. By analyzing the Fourier spectrum of error-mitigated time-series data, we successfully identify key signatures of $E_8$ symmetry despite hardware noise. These results validate the viability of both circuit compression and hardware-efficient compilation for probing complex topological phenomena on NISQ devices.

AI.tldr: Researchers demonstrate improved spectroscopy of confined excitations in transverse-field Ising model using two error-resilient circuit techniques on IBM quantum hardware, successfully identifying E8 symmetry signatures despite noise.
AI.motivation: The transverse-field Ising model is important for studying confinement and excitation spectra, particularly E8 symmetry near criticality. However, experimentally resolving Ising meson spectroscopy to verify these symmetries is challenging on near-term quantum hardware due to deep circuit requirements for real-time evolution.
AI.method: Two distinct error-resilient circuit construction techniques on IBM Torino device: (1) first-order Trotter decomposition using native fractional gates, and (2) tensor-network-based circuit compression via Riemannian optimization. Fourier spectrum analysis of error-mitigated time-series data.
AI.result: Successfully identified key signatures of E8 symmetry despite hardware noise by analyzing Fourier spectrum of error-mitigated time-series data.
AI.conclusion: Results validate the viability of both circuit compression and hardware-efficient compilation for probing complex topological phenomena on NISQ (Noisy Intermediate-Scale Quantum) devices.

title: Martingales, laminates and minimal Korn inequalities

AI.tldr: The paper reframes Chipot's problem about minimal measurements for Korn-type inequalities using rank-one convexity and quasiconvexity, obtaining sharp bounds: N(d,Ω)=2d(1-o(1)) and N'(d,Ω)=2d-1.
AI.motivation: To determine the minimal number of scalar measurements needed for Korn-type control on ∇u in H₀¹(Ω) and H¹(Ω) spaces, addressing Chipot's open question about N(d,Ω) and N'(d,Ω).
AI.method: Reformulates the problem using rank-one convexity and quasiconvexity theory, establishes algebraic characterization, and develops systematic connection between laminates and martingales to construct explicit families of laminates achieving bounds.
AI.result: Obtains sharp bounds: N(d,Ω)=2d(1-o(1)) and N'(d,Ω)=2d-1, recovers Chipot's results, establishes dimension-optimal Korn inequality, and provides sharp estimates for best constants in various Korn-type inequalities.
AI.conclusion: The laminate-martingale connection provides powerful method for variational calculus, enabling new quantitative proof of Ornstein's non-inequality and generalizing results to rectangular cases and L^p estimates.

title: Progress in relativistic laser-plasma interaction with kilotesla-level applied magnetic fields
summary: We report on progress in the understanding of the effects of kilotesla-level applied magnetic fields on relativistic laser-plasma interactions. Ongoing advances in magnetic-field-generation techniques enable new and highly desirable phenomena, including magnetic-field-amplification platforms with reversible sign, focusing ion acceleration, and bulk-relativistic plasma heating. Building on recent advancements in laser-plasma interactions with applied magnetic fields, we introduce simple models for evaluating the effects of applied magnetic fields in magnetic-field amplification, sheath-based ion acceleration, and direct laser acceleration. These models indicate the feasibility of observing beneficial magnetic-field effects under experimentally relevant conditions and offer a starting point for future experimental design.

AI.tldr: Researchers develop models to understand how kilotesla magnetic fields affect laser-plasma interactions, enabling new phenomena like magnetic field amplification and improved ion acceleration.
AI.motivation: Recent advances in generating strong magnetic fields (kilotesla level) create opportunities to explore new phenomena in laser-plasma interactions that were previously inaccessible, requiring better understanding of these magnetic field effects.
AI.method: The authors introduce simple analytical models to evaluate how applied magnetic fields affect three key areas: magnetic-field amplification platforms, sheath-based ion acceleration, and direct laser acceleration in plasma interactions.
AI.result: The models demonstrate that beneficial magnetic field effects can be observed under experimentally relevant conditions, providing a foundation for future experimental design in this emerging field.
AI.conclusion: Simple models effectively capture the essential physics of kilotesla magnetic field effects on laser-plasma interactions, showing feasibility for experimental observation and offering guidance for designing future experiments to harness these magnetic field effects.

title: Preconditioning a hybridizable discontinuous Galerkin method for Navier-Stokes at high Reynolds number
summary: We introduce a preconditioner for a hybridizable discontinuous Galerkin discretization of the linearized Navier-Stokes equations at high Reynolds number. The preconditioner is based on an augmented Lagrangian approach of the full discretization. Unlike standard grad-div type augmentation, however, we consider augmentation based on divergence-conformity. With this augmentation we introduce two different, well-conditioned, and easy to solve matrices to approximate the trace pressure Schur complement. To introduce a completely algebraic solver, we propose to use multifrontal sparse LU solvers using butterfly compression to solve the trace velocity block. Numerical examples demonstrate that the trace pressure Schur complement is highly robust in mesh spacing and Reynolds number and that the multifrontal inexact LU performs well for a wide range of Reynolds numbers.

AI.tldr: A preconditioner for hybridizable discontinuous Galerkin discretization of linearized Navier-Stokes equations at high Reynolds numbers, using divergence-conformity augmentation and multifrontal LU solvers with butterfly compression.
AI.motivation: Need efficient preconditioners for high Reynolds number Navier-Stokes simulations using hybridizable discontinuous Galerkin methods, particularly addressing challenges with mesh spacing and Reynolds number robustness.
AI.method: Augmented Lagrangian approach based on divergence-conformity (not standard grad-div), introducing two well-conditioned matrices to approximate trace pressure Schur complement, and using multifrontal sparse LU solvers with butterfly compression for trace velocity block.
AI.result: Trace pressure Schur complement is highly robust in mesh spacing and Reynolds number, and multifrontal inexact LU performs well across wide range of Reynolds numbers.
AI.conclusion: The proposed preconditioner provides an effective algebraic solver for high Reynolds number Navier-Stokes problems using hybridizable discontinuous Galerkin discretization, with demonstrated robustness and performance.

title: Efficient Simulation of the 2D Hubbard Model via Hilbert Space-Filling Curve Mapping
summary: We investigate tensor network simulations of the two-dimensional Hubbard model by mapping the lattice onto a one-dimensional chain using space-filling curves. In particular, we focus on the Hilbert curve, whose locality-preserving structure minimizes the range of effective interactions in the mapped model. This enables a more compact matrix product state (MPS) representation compared to conventional snake mapping. Through systematic benchmarks, we show that the Hilbert curve consistently yields lower ground-state energies at fixed bond dimension, with the advantage increasing for larger system sizes and in physically relevant interaction regimes. Our implementation reaches clusters up to $32\times32$ sites with open and periodic boundary conditions, delivering reliable ground-state energies and correlation functions in agreement with established results, but at significantly reduced computational cost. These findings establish space-filling curve mappings, particularly the Hilbert curve, as a powerful tool for extending tensor-network studies of strongly correlated two-dimensional quantum systems beyond the limits accessible with standard approaches.

AI.tldr: Space-filling curves (especially Hilbert curve) enable efficient tensor network simulations of 2D Hubbard model by mapping to 1D chain with minimal interaction range, outperforming conventional snake mapping.
AI.motivation: To extend tensor-network studies of strongly correlated 2D quantum systems beyond current limits by finding more efficient mappings that reduce computational cost while maintaining accuracy.
AI.method: Map 2D lattice to 1D chain using space-filling curves (particularly Hilbert curve) which preserves locality, minimizing effective interaction range. This enables compact matrix product state (MPS) representation. Systematic benchmarks compare Hilbert curve with conventional snake mapping.
AI.result: Hilbert curve consistently yields lower ground-state energies at fixed bond dimension, with advantages increasing for larger systems (up to 32×32 sites) and in physically relevant interaction regimes. Reliable ground-state energies and correlation functions obtained at significantly reduced computational cost.
AI.conclusion: Space-filling curve mappings, particularly the Hilbert curve, establish as powerful tool for extending tensor-network studies of strongly correlated 2D quantum systems beyond standard approach limits.

title: Swarming by curvature control in arbitrary dimension
summary: We consider an interacting particle system proposed in the literature to model fish behavior. In this model, the agents move at constant speed and control the curvature of their trajectory (i.e. the time-derivative of their velocity) so as to align their velocity with that of their neighbors, up to some noise. We provide a novel $n$-dimensional formulation of this model for any $n \geq 3$ and derive its mean-field kinetic formulation using bundle geometry concepts. The target of the paper is the derivation of a fluid model in the hydrodynamic limit. We show that this fluid model is the "self-organized hydrodynamic" (SOH) model already found in earlier work pertaining to the Vicsek model. The derivation is based on the introduction of appropriate "generalized collision invariants" (GCI). The action of the $n$-dimensional orthogonal group is used to reduce the expression of the GCI to a set of two functions satisfying a system of equations which is solved by means of a variational formulation. This leads to explicit formulas for the coefficients of the SOH model in terms of those of the original interacting particle system.

AI.tldr: The paper extends a fish behavior model to n-dimensions, derives its mean-field kinetic formulation using bundle geometry, and obtains the self-organized hydrodynamic (SOH) model in the hydrodynamic limit via generalized collision invariants.
AI.motivation: To provide a novel n-dimensional formulation of an existing fish behavior model and derive its hydrodynamic limit, connecting microscopic particle interactions to macroscopic fluid dynamics.
AI.method: Uses bundle geometry concepts for mean-field kinetic formulation, introduces generalized collision invariants (GCI), employs n-dimensional orthogonal group action to reduce GCI expressions, and solves resulting equations via variational formulation.
AI.result: Derives the self-organized hydrodynamic (SOH) model as the hydrodynamic limit, with explicit formulas connecting SOH coefficients to original particle system parameters.
AI.conclusion: The n-dimensional fish behavior model leads to the same SOH model found in Vicsek model studies, establishing mathematical connections between microscopic alignment dynamics and macroscopic hydrodynamic descriptions.

title: Qubit Lattice Algorithm Simulations of the Scattering of a Bounded Two Dimensional Electromagnetic Pulse from an Infinite Planar Dielectric Interface
summary: Qubit lattice algorithm (QLA) simulations are performed for a two-dimensional (2D) spatially bounded pulse propagating onto a plane interface between two dielectric slabs. QLA is an initial value scheme that consists of a sequence of unitary collision and streaming operators, with appropriate potential operators, that recover Maxwell equations in inhomogeneous dielectric media to second order in the lattice discreteness. For the case of total internal reflection, there is transient energy transfer into the second medium due to the evanescent fields as the Poynting unit vector of the pulse is rotated from its incident to reflected direction. Because of the finite spatial extent of the pulse, a self-consistent Goos-Hanchen-type displacement along the interface is found without imposing any explicit interface boundary conditions on the fields. For normal incidence. the standard Fresnel coefficients are recovered for appropriately averaged QLA fields. Energy is conserved at all times to seven significant figures.

AI.tldr: QLA simulations of 2D pulse propagation at dielectric interface show self-consistent Goos-Hanchen displacement without explicit boundary conditions, recover Fresnel coefficients, and conserve energy to high precision.
AI.motivation: To study electromagnetic pulse propagation at dielectric interfaces using quantum lattice algorithms, particularly examining transient phenomena like evanescent fields and Goos-Hanchen displacement without imposing explicit boundary conditions.
AI.method: Uses qubit lattice algorithm (QLA) - an initial value scheme with unitary collision and streaming operators plus potential operators that recover Maxwell equations in inhomogeneous media to second order in lattice discreteness.
AI.result: For total internal reflection: transient energy transfer into second medium due to evanescent fields, self-consistent Goos-Hanchen displacement along interface without explicit boundary conditions. For normal incidence: recovery of standard Fresnel coefficients. Energy conserved to seven significant figures.
AI.conclusion: QLA effectively simulates complex electromagnetic phenomena at dielectric interfaces, capturing subtle effects like Goos-Hanchen displacement self-consistently while maintaining high energy conservation and recovering classical results like Fresnel coefficients.

title: Relaxation Schemes for Flows in Networks: Application to Shallow Water and Blood Flow Equations
summary: A numerical scheme of relaxation type is proposed to approximate hyperbolic conservation laws in canal networks. Physical conditions at the junction are given and a novel strategy based on [Briani, Natalini, Ribot, 2025] is introduced to approximate the solution, avoiding the use of approximate Riemann solvers. This general approach is applied to shallow water and blood flow equations, dealing both the subcritical and the supercritical case. The relaxation scheme is complemented with a well-balanced strategy to treat source terms. We investigate properties of the numerical scheme and we present many numerical tests in different settings.

AI.tldr: A relaxation-type numerical scheme for hyperbolic conservation laws in canal networks, with novel junction handling avoiding Riemann solvers, applied to shallow water and blood flow equations.
AI.motivation: To develop an efficient numerical method for hyperbolic conservation laws in canal networks that avoids complex approximate Riemann solvers at junctions while handling both subcritical and supercritical flow regimes.
AI.method: A relaxation-type numerical scheme with a novel junction strategy based on Briani, Natalini, Ribot (2025), complemented with well-balanced treatment of source terms. Applied to shallow water and blood flow equations.
AI.result: The scheme successfully approximates solutions for hyperbolic conservation laws in canal networks, handling both subcritical and supercritical cases with proper junction conditions and source term treatment.
AI.conclusion: The proposed relaxation scheme with novel junction strategy provides an effective alternative to Riemann solver-based approaches for simulating hyperbolic conservation laws in canal networks across different flow regimes.

title: Rational regulation strategies of interstitial localized electrons in electride: A density functional theory study
summary: As a class of electron-rich materials, electrides demonstrate promising applications in many fields. However, the required high pressure restricts the practical applications to some extent. This study reveals that the unique feature of electride, i.e., the localization of interstitial electrons, can be greatly enhanced and tuned by self-defective doping, applying tensile/compressive stress, or shear stress. Moreover, the requirement of orbital orthogonality between the valence and core electron wave functions, as well as the Pauli exclusion principle, should be the driven force for the electron interstitial localization; and the exertion of external pressure modifies the available space to accommodate the electronic wave functions, thus enhances the interstitial localization. These discoveries lay down the ground for searching for promising electrides that are practicable at ambient conditions.

AI.tldr: Electride properties can be enhanced at ambient conditions through defect doping and stress manipulation, overcoming high-pressure limitations.
AI.motivation: Electrides have promising applications but require high pressure, limiting practical use. The study aims to find ways to enhance electride properties under ambient conditions.
AI.method: The study investigates enhancing electride properties through self-defective doping, applying tensile/compressive stress, and shear stress. It analyzes how orbital orthogonality requirements and Pauli exclusion drive electron interstitial localization.
AI.result: Electride properties can be significantly enhanced and tuned by defect doping and stress application. External pressure modifies available space for electronic wave functions, enhancing interstitial localization.
AI.conclusion: These discoveries provide a foundation for searching for practical electrides that work at ambient conditions, overcoming the high-pressure limitation.

title: On the growth properties of interior transmission eigenfunctions near corners
summary:
We investigate the localization and vanishing of $L^2$ interior transmission eigenfunctions at corners. Past numerical computations suggest that these eigenfunctions localize at non-convex corners. This phenomenon has, however, not been proven theoretically. We show that localization does indeed occur for some eigenfunctions at a non-convex corner.
  We also investigate the vanishing of interior transmission eigenfunctions at a convex corner. We prove that these eigenfunctions vanish at convex corners with reduced smoothness assumptions compared to earlier results.

AI.tldr: The paper proves that L² interior transmission eigenfunctions localize at non-convex corners and vanish at convex corners with weaker smoothness assumptions.
AI.motivation: Numerical evidence suggests interior transmission eigenfunctions localize at non-convex corners, but this phenomenon lacks theoretical proof. Additionally, existing results on vanishing at convex corners require strong smoothness assumptions.
AI.method: Theoretical analysis of L² interior transmission eigenfunctions at corners, likely using mathematical analysis techniques to study localization behavior at non-convex corners and vanishing properties at convex corners with reduced regularity requirements.
AI.result: 1) Proves localization does occur for some eigenfunctions at non-convex corners, confirming numerical observations. 2) Proves eigenfunctions vanish at convex corners with weaker smoothness assumptions than previous results.
AI.conclusion: The paper provides rigorous mathematical justification for the localization phenomenon at non-convex corners and extends the vanishing result at convex corners under less restrictive smoothness conditions, advancing the theoretical understanding of interior transmission eigenfunctions.

title: Dynamo and Jet interconnections in GRMHD simulations of black hole accretion disks
summary: We present global 3D GRMHD simulations of black hole (BH) accretion disks designed to investigate how MRI-driven dynamo action regulates jet formation and evolution. Unlike standard SANE/MAD setups that impose a coherent large-scale poloidal loop, our "sub-SANE" initial conditions use multiple same-polarity small-scale magnetic loops. Rapid reconnection erases magnetic memory and enables large-scale dynamo to emerge early from MRI turbulence. We perform two such sub-SANE simulations at different BH spins ($a = 0.5, 0.9375$) and compare them with conventional SANE runs. The sub-SANE disks show regular large-scale dynamo cycles with periods of about ten orbits. Decomposition of the induction equation shows that the turbulent dynamo term is stronger in 3D compared to 2.5D and balances advection in the saturated state, confirming sustained large-scale field generation. These dynamo-generated fields are advected inward with minimal time lag, producing correlated peaks in both poloidal and toroidal field strengths from $r_{\rm max}$ to the horizon. Early in the evolution, these peaks imprint directly onto the jet's electromagnetic energy flux, indicating that the jet mirrors the dynamo wave. Though jets form at early times, the sub-SANE runs eventually undergo jet shutdown. We show that this occurs when the magnetic field at the horizon loses coherence, as quantified by a decline in the signed-to-unsigned flux ratio $\mathcal{C}_{\rm BH}$ below $\approx 0.6$. In contrast, the SANE reference case with similar accretion rate and horizon magnetic flux maintains high magnetic coherence because its initial large-scale field persists, allowing its jet to survive. Our results show that both dynamo-driven field evolution and horizon magnetic-field coherence critically regulate jet longevity, establishing a direct dynamo-jet connection in GRMHD disks.

AI.tldr: 3D GRMHD simulations show MRI-driven dynamo cycles regulate jet formation in black hole accretion disks, with jet shutdown occurring when magnetic field coherence at horizon drops below critical threshold.
AI.motivation: To investigate how MRI-driven dynamo action regulates jet formation and evolution in black hole accretion disks, moving beyond standard SANE/MAD setups that impose coherent large-scale magnetic fields.
AI.method: Global 3D GRMHD simulations with "sub-SANE" initial conditions using multiple small-scale magnetic loops, compared with conventional SANE runs at different black hole spins. Analysis includes decomposition of induction equation and tracking magnetic field coherence.
AI.result: Sub-SANE disks show regular large-scale dynamo cycles (~10 orbits), with turbulent dynamo balancing advection. Jets form early but eventually shut down when magnetic field coherence at horizon (quantified by signed-to-unsigned flux ratio) drops below ~0.6, unlike SANE cases where initial large-scale field persists.
AI.conclusion: Both dynamo-driven field evolution and horizon magnetic-field coherence critically regulate jet longevity, establishing a direct connection between dynamo action and jet behavior in GRMHD accretion disks.

title: Simulation and inference methods for non-Markovian stochastic biochemical reaction networks
summary: Stochastic models of biochemical reaction networks are widely used to capture intrinsic noise in cellular systems. The typical formulation of these models are based on Markov processes for which there is extensive research on efficient simulation and inference. However, there are biological processes, such as gene transcription and translation, that introduce history dependent dynamics requiring non-Markovian processes to accurately capture the stochastic dynamics of the system. This greater realism comes with additional computational challenges for simulation and parameter inference. We develop efficient stochastic simulation algorithms for well-mixed non-Markovian stochastic biochemical reaction networks with delays that depend on system state and time. Our methods generalize the next reaction method and $τ$-leaping method to support arbitrary inter-event time distributions while preserving computational scalability. We also introduce a coupling scheme to generate exact non-Markovian sample paths that are positively correlated to an approximate non-Markovian $τ$-leaping sample path. This enables substantial computational gains for Bayesian inference of model parameters though multifidelity simulation-based inference schemes. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach on a gene regulation model with delayed auto-inhibition, showing substantial gains in both simulation accuracy and inference efficiency of two orders of magnitude. These results extend the practical applicability of non-Markovian models in systems biology and beyond.

AI.tldr: Efficient simulation algorithms for non-Markovian biochemical reaction networks with delays, enabling scalable simulation and Bayesian inference with orders of magnitude speedup.
AI.motivation: Biological processes like gene transcription/translation require non-Markovian models to capture history-dependent dynamics, but existing methods face computational challenges for simulation and parameter inference.
AI.method: Developed stochastic simulation algorithms generalizing next reaction method and τ-leaping to support arbitrary inter-event time distributions. Introduced coupling scheme to generate exact non-Markovian sample paths positively correlated with approximate τ-leaping paths.
AI.result: Demonstrated effectiveness on gene regulation model with delayed auto-inhibition, showing substantial gains in both simulation accuracy and inference efficiency (two orders of magnitude improvement).
AI.conclusion: The approach extends practical applicability of non-Markovian models in systems biology by enabling efficient simulation and Bayesian inference for history-dependent biochemical networks.

title: Modulation of DNA rheology by a transcription factor that forms aging microgels
summary: Proteins and nucleic acids form non-Newtonian liquids with complex rheological properties that contribute to their function in vivo. Here we investigate the rheology of the transcription factor NANOG, a key protein in sustaining embryonic stem cell self-renewal. We discover that at high concentrations NANOG forms macroscopic aging gels through its intrinsically disordered tryptophan-rich domain. By combining molecular dynamics simulations, mass photometry and Cryo-EM, we also discover that NANOG forms self-limiting micelle-like clusters which expose their DNA-binding domains. In dense solutions of DNA, NANOG micelle-like structures stabilize intermolecular entanglements and crosslinks, forming microgel-like structures. Our findings suggest that NANOG may contribute to regulate gene expression in a unconventional way: by restricting and stabilizing genome dynamics at key transcriptional sites through the formation of an aging microgel-like structure, potentially enabling mechanical memory in the gene network.

AI.tldr: NANOG forms aging gels and micelle-like clusters that stabilize DNA entanglements, potentially enabling mechanical memory in gene regulation.
AI.motivation: To understand how transcription factors like NANOG, which sustains embryonic stem cell self-renewal, might regulate gene expression through non-Newtonian rheological properties and physical interactions with DNA.
AI.method: Combined molecular dynamics simulations, mass photometry, and Cryo-EM to investigate NANOG's structural and rheological properties at high concentrations.
AI.result: NANOG forms macroscopic aging gels via its intrinsically disordered tryptophan-rich domain, creates self-limiting micelle-like clusters that expose DNA-binding domains, and stabilizes DNA entanglements into microgel-like structures in dense DNA solutions.
AI.conclusion: NANOG may regulate gene expression unconventionally by forming aging microgel-like structures that restrict and stabilize genome dynamics at transcriptional sites, potentially enabling mechanical memory in gene networks.

title: The Obukhov--Corrsin spectrum of passive scalar turbulence through anomalous regularization
summary: The Obukhov--Corrsin spectrum predicts the distribution of Fourier mass for a passive scalar field advected by a "turbulent" velocity field with spatial regularity $C^α_x$ for $α\in (0,1)$ and subject to a time-stationary forcing. We prove the Obukhov--Corrsin spectrum holds after summing over geometric annuli in Fourier space -- up to logarithmic corrections -- as a consequence of a sharp anomalous regularization result. We then prove this anomalous regularization for a broad class of Kraichnan-type models. The proof of anomalous regularization relies on a Fourier space $\ell^p$ energy equality and a weighted lattice Poincaré inequality.

AI.tldr: The paper proves the Obukhov-Corrsin spectrum for passive scalars in turbulent flows, showing it holds up to logarithmic corrections via anomalous regularization analysis.
AI.motivation: To establish rigorous mathematical foundations for the Obukhov-Corrsin spectrum prediction in turbulent passive scalar transport, which describes Fourier mass distribution for scalar fields advected by turbulent velocity fields.
AI.method: Uses Fourier space ℓ^p energy equality and weighted lattice Poincaré inequality to prove anomalous regularization for Kraichnan-type models, then demonstrates the spectrum holds after summing over geometric annuli in Fourier space.
AI.result: Proves the Obukhov-Corrsin spectrum holds (up to logarithmic corrections) as a consequence of sharp anomalous regularization, and establishes this regularization for a broad class of Kraichnan-type models.
AI.conclusion: The Obukhov-Corrsin spectrum prediction is mathematically validated through anomalous regularization techniques, providing rigorous support for this fundamental result in turbulent scalar transport theory.

title: Solitary Alfvén Waves
summary: We present a three-dimensional numerical model of a solitary spherically polarized Alfvén wave packet -- an Alfvénon, characterized by open field-line topology and magnetic field reversals, resembling the switchbacks observed by Parker Solar Probe to be a nearly ubiquitous feature of turbulence in the inner heliosphere. Direct magnetohydrodynamic simulations of the constructed Alfvénon demonstrates remarkable stability, confirming its nature as an exact, nonlinear solution of the ideal MHD equations.

AI.tldr: Researchers present a 3D numerical model of a solitary spherically polarized Alfvén wave packet (Alfvénon) that matches Parker Solar Probe observations of switchbacks in solar wind turbulence.
AI.motivation: To understand the nature of switchbacks observed by Parker Solar Probe in the inner heliosphere, which appear as nearly ubiquitous features of turbulence with open field-line topology and magnetic field reversals.
AI.method: Developed a three-dimensional numerical model of a solitary spherically polarized Alfvén wave packet (Alfvénon), then performed direct magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) simulations to test its stability.
AI.result: The constructed Alfvénon demonstrates remarkable stability in MHD simulations, confirming it as an exact, nonlinear solution of the ideal MHD equations.
AI.conclusion: The Alfvénon provides a theoretical framework for understanding switchbacks observed in solar wind turbulence, representing a stable, nonlinear MHD solution that matches observational characteristics.

title: A Note on the Conditions for COS Convergence
summary: We study the truncation error of the COS method and give simple, verifiable conditions that guarantee convergence. In one dimension, COS is admissible when the density belongs to both L1 and L2 and has a finite weighted L2 moment of order strictly greater than one. We extend the result to multiple dimensions by requiring the moment order to exceed the dimension. These conditions enlarge the class of densities covered by previous analyses and include heavy-tailed distributions such as Student t with small degrees of freedom.

AI.tldr: The paper analyzes truncation error conditions for COS method convergence, extending coverage to heavy-tailed distributions like Student t.
AI.motivation: To establish verifiable conditions that guarantee convergence of the COS method for a broader class of probability densities, including heavy-tailed distributions that were not covered by previous analyses.
AI.method: The authors study the truncation error of the COS method and derive simple, verifiable conditions for convergence. In one dimension, they require the density to belong to both L1 and L2 spaces and have a finite weighted L2 moment of order strictly greater than one. For multiple dimensions, they extend this by requiring the moment order to exceed the dimension.
AI.result: The proposed conditions enlarge the class of densities covered by previous analyses and include heavy-tailed distributions such as Student t with small degrees of freedom, which were previously excluded from convergence guarantees.
AI.conclusion: The paper provides more general convergence conditions for the COS method that cover a wider range of probability densities, including heavy-tailed distributions, making the method applicable to a broader set of practical problems in finance and other fields.

title: Ground state solutions of $p$-Laplacian equations with nonnegative potentials on Lattice graphs
summary:
In this paper, we study the $p$-Laplacian equation
  $$
  -Δ_p u + V(x)|u|^{p-2}u = f(x,u)
  $$
  on the lattice graph $\mathbb{Z}^N$ with nonnegative potentials. By employing the Nehari manifold method, we establish the existence of ground state solutions under suitable growth conditions on the nonlinearity $f(x,u)$, provided that the potential $V(x)$ is either periodic or bounded. Moreover, we prove that if $f$ is odd in $u$, then the above equation admits infinitely many geometrically distinct solutions. Finally, we extend these results from $\mathbb{Z}^N$ to the more general setting of Cayley graphs.

AI.tldr: Existence of ground state and infinitely many solutions for p-Laplacian equations on lattice graphs with nonnegative potentials using Nehari manifold method.
AI.motivation: To study p-Laplacian equations on discrete structures like lattice graphs, extending PDE results from continuous to discrete settings, particularly on $\mathbb{Z}^N$ and Cayley graphs.
AI.method: Employ the Nehari manifold method to establish existence results under suitable growth conditions on nonlinearity f(x,u), with potential V(x) being periodic or bounded.
AI.result: Proved existence of ground state solutions when V(x) is periodic or bounded. When f is odd in u, established infinitely many geometrically distinct solutions. Extended results from $\mathbb{Z}^N$ to Cayley graphs.
AI.conclusion: The Nehari manifold method effectively establishes existence results for p-Laplacian equations on discrete graphs, with extensions to more general graph structures possible.

title: Pruning AMR: Efficient Visualization of Implicit Neural Representations via Weight Matrix Analysis
summary: An implicit neural representation (INR) is a neural network that approximates a spatiotemporal function. Many memory-intensive visualization tasks, including modern 4D CT scanning methods, represent data natively as INRs. While INRs are prized for being more memory-efficient than traditional data stored on a lattice, many visualization tasks still require discretization to a regular grid. We present PruningAMR, an algorithm that builds a mesh with resolution adapted to geometric features encoded by the INR. To identify these geometric features, we use an interpolative decomposition pruning method on the weight matrices of the INR. The resulting pruned network is used to guide adaptive mesh refinement, enabling automatic mesh generation tailored to the underlying resolution of the function. Starting from a pre-trained INR--without access to its training data--we produce a variable resolution visualization with substantial memory savings.

AI.tldr: PruningAMR is an algorithm that creates adaptive resolution meshes from implicit neural representations (INRs) by pruning network weights to identify geometric features, enabling memory-efficient visualization without needing original training data.
AI.motivation: Many visualization tasks using INRs still require discretization to regular grids, which can be memory-intensive. There's a need for automatic mesh generation that adapts to the underlying resolution of the function encoded by INRs, especially when original training data is unavailable.
AI.method: Uses interpolative decomposition pruning on INR weight matrices to identify geometric features. The pruned network guides adaptive mesh refinement, creating variable resolution meshes tailored to the function's underlying resolution.
AI.result: Produces variable resolution visualizations with substantial memory savings. Works from pre-trained INRs without access to original training data, enabling automatic mesh generation adapted to geometric features.
AI.conclusion: PruningAMR provides an effective method for memory-efficient visualization of INR data by creating adaptive meshes based on geometric features identified through network pruning, addressing the memory limitations of traditional grid-based approaches.

title: Notes on Regularity theory for Nonlinear elliptic equations
summary: In this note, we present several seminal developments in the regularity theory of nonlinear (uniformly) elliptic equations, including the De Giorgi--Nash--Moser theory concerning the Hilbert 19th problem and variational equations, as well as the Krylov--Safonov and Evans--Safonov theories for fully nonlinear equations.

AI.tldr: Survey paper reviewing key developments in regularity theory for nonlinear elliptic equations, covering De Giorgi-Nash-Moser theory for Hilbert's 19th problem and Krylov-Safonov/Evans-Safonov theories for fully nonlinear equations.
AI.motivation: To provide a comprehensive overview of foundational results in the regularity theory of nonlinear elliptic equations, highlighting the historical development and importance of these theories in solving fundamental problems in partial differential equations.
AI.method: The paper presents a survey/note format that reviews and synthesizes existing theories rather than developing new methods. It covers three main theoretical frameworks: 1) De Giorgi-Nash-Moser theory for uniformly elliptic equations, 2) Krylov-Safonov theory for fully nonlinear equations, and 3) Evans-Safonov theory for fully nonlinear equations.
AI.result: The paper organizes and presents the key results from these seminal theories, showing how they address regularity questions for nonlinear elliptic equations, including Hölder continuity estimates, existence of classical solutions, and connections to Hilbert's 19th problem.
AI.conclusion: These theories represent fundamental breakthroughs in understanding the regularity properties of solutions to nonlinear elliptic equations, with De Giorgi-Nash-Moser solving Hilbert's 19th problem for variational equations, and Krylov-Safonov/Evans-Safonov extending regularity theory to fully nonlinear equations.

title: A New Proof of the Abstract Random Tensor Estimate by Deng, Nahmod, and Yue
summary: We provide a new proof of the abstract random tensor estimate, which was established by Deng, Nahmod, and Yue (2022) using the moment method. The key new tool is the direct use of the non-commutative Khintchine inequality with the probabilistic decoupling of the product of Gaussians. We use Hermite and generalized Laguerre-type polynomials allow us to account for pairings in the real and complex-valued Gaussians, respectively, and remove the square-free (tetrahedral) requirement.

AI.tldr: New proof of abstract random tensor estimate using non-commutative Khintchine inequality with probabilistic decoupling of Gaussian products, removing square-free requirement.
