AI.motivation: To provide an alternative proof to the abstract random tensor estimate established by Deng, Nahmod, and Yue (2022) using the moment method, by developing a more direct approach.
AI.method: Uses non-commutative Khintchine inequality with probabilistic decoupling of Gaussian products. Employs Hermite and generalized Laguerre-type polynomials to handle pairings in real and complex-valued Gaussians respectively.
AI.result: Successfully proves the abstract random tensor estimate without requiring the square-free (tetrahedral) condition that was needed in the original proof.
AI.conclusion: The new proof technique using non-commutative Khintchine inequality and polynomial methods provides a more direct approach to the random tensor estimate and removes previous technical restrictions.

title: Anderson localization in high-contrast media with random spherical inclusions
summary: We study spectral properties of partial differential operators modelling composite materials with highly contrasting constituents, comprised of soft spherical inclusions with random radii dispersed in a stiff matrix. Such operators have recently attracted significant interest from the research community, including in the context of stochastic homogenization. In particular, it has been proved that the spectrum of these operators may feature a band-gap structure in the regime where heterogeneities take place on a sufficiently small scale. However, the nature of the limiting (as the small scale tends to zero) spectrum in the above setting is non-classical and not completely understood. In this paper we prove for the first time that Anderson localization occurs near band edges, thus shedding light on the limiting spectral behaviour. Our results rely on recent nontrivial advancements in quantitative unique continuation for PDEs, in combination with assumptions on the model that are standard in the Anderson localization literature, and which we plan to relax in future works.

AI.tldr: The paper proves Anderson localization near band edges for PDE operators modeling composite materials with highly contrasting constituents, using quantitative unique continuation techniques.
AI.motivation: To understand the limiting spectral behavior of PDE operators modeling composite materials with soft spherical inclusions in a stiff matrix, particularly when heterogeneities occur on small scales. Previous work showed these operators may have band-gap structure, but the nature of the limiting spectrum as scale tends to zero is not fully understood.
AI.method: Uses recent advancements in quantitative unique continuation for PDEs, combined with standard assumptions from Anderson localization literature. The approach focuses on proving localization near band edges in the spectrum.
AI.result: First proof that Anderson localization occurs near band edges for these operators, providing insight into the limiting spectral behavior as the small scale tends to zero.
AI.conclusion: The paper establishes Anderson localization near band edges for composite material operators, advancing understanding of their spectral properties. The authors plan to relax current assumptions in future work.

title: Self-Expanding Solutions to the Mean Curvature Flow for Multiphase Surfaces with Regular Junctions
summary: We consider a multiphase surface $\mathcal{C}_0$ in $\mathbb{R}^3$ consisting of a finite number of surfaces passing through the origin , where all 1-dimensional junctions are regular triple junctions in which three planes meet at the same angle and each surface scales down homothetically to a limit curve of finite length. We prove the existence of self-similar expanding solutions of the mean curvature flow on the multiphase surface initially given by $\mathcal{C}_0$. For this initial condition, there are multiple solutions that are combinations of the regular triple junctions and regular quadruple points, where four regular triple junctions meet at an angle of approximately $109.5^{\circ}$.

AI.tldr: Existence of self-similar expanding solutions for mean curvature flow on multiphase surfaces with regular triple junctions and quadruple points.
AI.motivation: To study the behavior of mean curvature flow on complex multiphase surfaces with singularities, particularly understanding how self-similar solutions emerge from surfaces with regular triple junctions and quadruple points.
AI.method: Analyze multiphase surfaces in ℝ³ with finite surfaces passing through origin, where 1D junctions are regular triple junctions (three planes meeting at equal angles) and surfaces scale homothetically to finite-length limit curves. Prove existence of self-similar expanding solutions for mean curvature flow starting from such initial conditions.
AI.result: Proved existence of self-similar expanding solutions for mean curvature flow on multiphase surfaces with initial condition C₀. Multiple solutions exist combining regular triple junctions and regular quadruple points where four triple junctions meet at approximately 109.5°.
AI.conclusion: Complex multiphase surfaces with regular geometric singularities (triple junctions and quadruple points) admit self-similar expanding solutions under mean curvature flow, revealing rich solution structures for such geometric evolution equations.

title: Bright and dark breathers on an elliptic wave in the defocusing mKdV equation
summary: Breathers on an elliptic wave background consist of nonlinear superpositions of a soliton and a periodic wave, both traveling with different wave speeds and interacting periodically in the space-time. For the defocusing modified Korteweg-de Vries (mKdV) equation, the construction of general breathers has been an open problem since the elliptic wave is related to the elliptic degeneration of the hyperelliptic solutions of genus two. We have found the new representation of eigenfunctions of the Lax operator associated with the elliptic wave, which enables us to solve this open problem and to construct two families of breathers with bright (elevation) and dark (depression) profiles.

AI.tldr: Constructs breathers on elliptic wave background for defocusing mKdV equation using new eigenfunction representation, solving long-standing open problem.
AI.motivation: Breathers on elliptic wave backgrounds combine solitons and periodic waves with different speeds, but constructing general breathers for defocusing mKdV had been an open problem due to elliptic degeneration of hyperelliptic solutions.
AI.method: Developed new representation of eigenfunctions for the Lax operator associated with elliptic wave background, enabling solution of the breather construction problem.
AI.result: Successfully constructed two families of breathers: bright (elevation) and dark (depression) profiles on elliptic wave backgrounds for defocusing mKdV equation.
AI.conclusion: The new eigenfunction representation solves the long-standing open problem of constructing general breathers on elliptic wave backgrounds for defocusing mKdV equation.
